content.body: wishes Gmail didn't destroy his careful formatting by using a variable-width font
thinks the gmail devil is laughing
i don't quite understand the difference beween <object> and <embed>
perhaps its a legacy thing
though i've seen <embed> as a child of <object>
hendry: <object> has fallback content, <embed> does not. that's the main difference
gsnedders: thanks
hendry: seen this? http://www.faculty.idc.ac.il/arik/IMRet-All.mov
(content adaptation)
(browser crash)
It seems to be working this time :)
hsivonen: woo, thanks for the link
hsivonen: that's amazing. though I guess it's going to require a 'bit of work', hence server side. Also that stuff with faces....
hsivonen: i remember you doing some jp2 tests. any future thoughts? I guess we will be playing around with jpg/png for sometime to come...
hendry: PNG has much better characteristics when it comes to downloading less data in order to render a smaller image
(assuming Adam interlacing)

hendry: the problem is that the current crop of browsers downloads full PNGs, and one would want the current browsers to load quarter data and new browsers versions for HD desktop displays to load full images
that would make sense
hsivonen: do you have an opinion on Opera's img { display: none;} ?
hendry: I don't.
hendry: is it that Opera doesn't load the HTTP resource but other browsers do?
hsivonen: yeah
seems reasonable
the canonical way to preload images from a script is new Image
in html5 it's speced that img must download
hendry: I don't understand the problem space well enough to have an educated opinion right now
hsivonen: how do you come across this 'Adam interlacing' stuff? do you have tests?
hendry: in the PNG spec :-)
hendry: http://www.schaik.com/pngsuite/pngsuite_int_png.html
is there some reason why "the current crop of browsers" don't implement interlaced aware downloads?
because I am always thinking that if images were somehow well dealt with for mobile env., we'd see a massive break through
hendry: I'm not sure. but I'd be surprised if current browsers stopped PNG downloads after a quarter of data when the display size to device pixels only needs a quarter of the samples
hendry: I haven't actually tested
hendry: I'd be happy to have guessed wrong :-)
gotta go
hsivonen: cheers

(on real-world content, too)
Hmm, Safari does about the same as HTML5 (except it doesn't even create the img element)
http://hasteworld.co.uk/ has exactly the same error message too - the whole page is blank in Safari (and HTML5)
Lachy: someone sent me mail saying a blog post was pending

Hixie: I made some changes to the multipage-generator so it splits into more sensible-sized sections and tries to redirect users when things have moved - would it be possible/convenient some time to set that up on whatwg.org?
iirc i had to make a bunch of changes to get it to work in my current setup
i'll have to look into it
ping me during the week some time?
Okay, sure
the current setup on whatwg.org is complicated -- the files get sent off to a server in the uk for splitting, and that's where your script actually runs
then it gets sent back to whatwg.org as a tarball and extracted
http://www.whatwg.org/issues/
Hixie: When registering, I got the "Your code is: ..." email twice
(I suppose I might have accidentally double-clicked, though)
(but I don't think I did)
After seemingly having logged in with that code, it still says "You must be logged in to vote."
If I log in with an invalid address/code, it doesn't actually do anything different - it just reloads the page with ?email=x%40y.com&code=z and nothing much happens
In FF3, the whole page just says "Scripting error: Script error. in javascript:%20eval(__firebugTemp__); line 0" (plus a Reload button)
(perhaps partly because I've got a half-broken Firebug installed)
Oh, now it says "Scripting error: document.getElementById("no-js-warning") has no properties in http://www.whatwg.org/issues/ line 157"
IE6 (in Wine) has nothing other than a single empty button on the page
(My earlier problems were in Opera)
Aha, Konqueror can log in
but nothing happens when clicking a "vote" button
(Browser interoperability is fun!)
Nice idea, though :-)

I think it would be nice if you could vote on a whole category, rather than having to choose specific emails, since e.g. someone implementing <video> would probably want all of the graphics-video issues to be addressed
Philip`: what browser?
i only tested firefox3 and safari3
I was using Opera 9.2 first
yeah opera has some weird bugs
i didn't work around any bugs in this
you'll need a 100% compliant browser :-)
(for the things i use)
interesting idea regarding voting for a category
though i don't really want to allow that since the categories can change on a whim
Aha, it seems to work in FF3 if I remove Firebug
It also looks like the vote I made in Konqueror did actually get counted, though it didn't give me any feedback in the browser (whereas it does give feedback in FF3)
cool
will hunt down the bugs in opera tomorrow
Is it intentional that it doesn't say who each email is from?
yes
So much for HTML 5 being backward-compatible :-P
